The following is a letter sent to LCM parents and guardians from Superintendent Stacey Brister. Parents,

I hope this email finds you well into your recovery efforts from Hurricane Laura. LCM has secured services to dry out our buildings, sanitized the freezers and received new food products, and made necessary repairs to our buses to make our campuses safe for students and staff to return to school.

We are continuing to work with the Texas Education Agency on missed days and will propose a new calendar, possibly with additional days added to the school year, once the waiver days are secured. The District will begin the process of making up instructional minutes by adding an additional 5 minutes to the school day beginning Monday, September 14th.

We appreciate your willingness to work with us as we continue efforts to repair our facilities.

.....There will be no change in starting times and the ending times should only amount to a few extra minutes.

Out of an abundance of caution, due to the threat of severe weather from storms Marco and Laura, LCMCISD will be closed from Monday, August 24 through Friday,

Because of the uncertainty of the storms reaching landfall and the possibilities of rain and high winds from the storms, we feel this closure is in the best interest of our students and staff and their families. Superintendents of Orange County have been following storm reports and agree that this is the best course of action.

All sporting events and games from all LCM campuses will be cancelled this week, August 24-28. This will include any activities scheduled for Saturday August 29. All gyms and facilities will also be closed.

Please continue to monitor the this Facebook page and your e-mail for messages as information becomes available.

DILEO & WOZNIAK PLACE – LADY BEARS GOLF TAKES THIRD
February 24 (Village Mills) – The Lady Bears played in the two-day Regional Preview in Huntsville Friday and Saturday and were back at it Monday morning as they teed it up in the Warren Invitational at Wildwood Golf Course. LC-M finished 3rd overall with a combined score of 438. The Hardin-Jefferson girls won 1st with a score of 390 and Bridge City was 2nd with a 433. Montana Dileo led the Lady Bears with an 83 to take 2nd place and Neely Wozniak fired a 90 to finish fourth overall. Rounding out the scoring for LC-M was Jaycie Benton with a 130 and Trinity Williams finished with a 135.

Read...educate yourself....tell your children.... see what’s going on around us...do something to make a difference.

Six Little Cypress-Mauriceville High School athletes have been named as Texas Army National Guard and the Texas High School Coaches Association (THSCA) 2019-2020 Academic All-State Recipients.

Honorable Mention includes Ethan McCollum, Landon Bearden, Tyler Rhodes and Kyle White. Max Greer and Matthew Lopez were named Second Team.

According to the THSCA website, “We understand that students’ performance in the classroom can sometimes be difficult to manage while participating in athletics, but their hard work has not gone unnoticed. The THSCA Academic All-State Teams recognize high school athletes who excel in the following categories: GPA, class rank and ACT/SAT score. These students are being recognized as a team member based on their scores in these categories. We applaud them for their commitment and dedication to perform with the highest of excellence academically and on the field or court.”

College Board has changed its procedures and deadlines for ordering our AP exams. Students who are planning to take AP exams must now register in November instead of March.

One day as Seymour is seeking a new mysterious plant, he finds a very mysterious unidentified plant which he calls Audrey II. The plant seems to have a craving for blood and soon begins to sing for his supper. Soon enough, Seymour feeds Audrey's sadistic dentist boyfriend to the plant and later, Mushnik for witnessing the death of Audrey's ex. Will Audrey II take over the world or will Seymour and Audrey defeat it?

Among the many staff and volunteers working together to save materials and equipment from the water soaked classrooms were Key Club members, led by their school sponsor, science teacher Woody Cox. One of the people to show up to help at Mauriceville Middle School was Pastor Brad McKenzie, who is the Texas Oklahoma Region 2 Trustee for Kiwanis, the civic organization that sponsors Key Club.

On Friday, my three classes participated in International Dot Day!

International Dot Day is observed annually around September 15th “ish”.
It is a holiday where people of all ages are encouraged to use their creativity and make their mark on the world.

Our classes (Jones/Perry/Purgahn) had a great day!
You couldn’t miss us in the halls because we were dressed in our “Dots”!

We incorporated dots into ALL of our subjects! We read The Dot by Peter Reynolds and discussed making our mark to see where it will take us. We have been learning about the neighboring states of Texas and filled in a teacher-made connect the dots page and labeling, we have also been learning about adding and subtracting decimals, so we practiced dropping the dot into our answer using dots. We also each created our own dot (goal in life, or dream) and watched it come to life using our campus IPads and the Quiver app, and a very sweet mom brought donuts for snack! What a sweet treat that looked like a dot! #LCI #4thgrade #dotday #internationaldotday #lcmcisd

A special meeting of the Little Cypress-Mauriceville Board of Trustees was held on Monday, August 26, for a public hearing for the 2019-2020 Budget and the tax rate. The Board elected to adopt a tax rate of $1.36 for the 2019-2020 school year. This rate includes $0.97 for Maintenance and Operations (M&O) and $0.39 for Interest and Sinking (I&S).

The I&S rate will stay the same as last year. These are funds that can only be used to make the district's bond payments. The amount reflects a $0.20 decrease from the prior year, which on a $100,000 home is a savings of $42 to the taxpayer.

The budget for 2019-2020 totaling $38,797,162. 00 was also adopted.

BUS BUDDIES...
The first two days of school, volunteers, administrators and staff rode along on the elementary buses to help drivers in any way they could. There are lots of little guys who have never been to school before and definitely have never ridden a bus, so there may be some tears, confusion about when to get off the bus and why it’s important to stay in your seat. It was an eye-opening experience for all who volunteered.

This was organized by Greg and Diana Perry, two recent retirees from LCM. Greg was the Assistant Superintendent and Diana a diagnostician at the high school. Photos are of those volunteers.
